title: Prader–Willi syndrome
summary: Prader–Willi syndrome (PWS) is a genetic disorder caused by a loss of function of specific genes on chromosome 15.[3] In newborns, symptoms include weak muscles, poor feeding, and slow development.[3] Beginning in childhood, those affected become constantly hungry, which often leads to obesity and type 2 diabetes.[3] Mild to moderate intellectual impairment and behavioral problems are also typical of the disorder.[3] Often, affected individuals have a narrow forehead, small hands and feet, short height, light skin and hair. Most are unable to have children.[3]
